An orderly queue for The Boss at Christchurch 'roll call' CHARLIE MITCHELL Last updated 21:21, February 20 2017 GEORGE HEARD/FAIRFAX NZ 
Glen McCartney ticking off fans at the Bruce Springsteen roll call. 
Days before Bruce Springsteen's first Christchurch show, his biggest fans formed an orderly queue in the rain, checked themselves in, and left. 
They come back several times a day, rain or shine, and repeat the process. 
The "roll call" is a fan-driven ritual unique to The Boss, which has made its way to Christchurch. 
The rules are simple: the first to line up is given the number one. Each person who follows is given a corresponding number. 
READ MORE: 
Each person must check in several times a day until the day of the concert. If they miss a roll call, they lose their number. 
Those who make every roll call enter the show in the order they first arrived. 
On the eve of the concert, hundreds still have their numbers as they check in for the third time of the day. 
The Christchurch roll call began with local Glen McCartney, who claimed the number one spot at 11am on Friday. As the first in the queue, he took on much of the responsibility; he arrives at 6am each day to check-in his fellow fans. 
"It's a lot of work. I'm here 11, 12 hours a day," he said. 
He wasn't the first to arrive. An Auckland woman was, but she gave up her number one spot because he was a local. 
Being number one meant he could go right up to the stage, metres away from Springsteen. 
"He gave me his harmonica in Auckland in 2014. That was something special." 
Number four in the line, Tresca Forrester, said the Christchurch roll call was made up of people from around the globe. 
"We've got about 50 per cent locals in the line, but we've got people from the UK, Australia, America and a whole lot of European countries as well. It's quite remarkable." 
She said The Boss's first Christchurch show would be a special one.
